name: Blesbok
description: The blesbok is easily recognized by its short body and the distinctive shape of its horns, present in both males and females.
food_note: Grasses and other plants; they drink daily, multiple times if possible.
image_alt: Blesbok, photo: Tereza Mrhálková, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length 130–160 cm; tail length 30–45 cm; shoulder height 85–120 cm; male weight 65–80 kg, female weight 55–70 kg; horn length up to 50 cm
reproduction: Females are pregnant for 225–300 days, giving birth to a single calf weighing about 7 kg, initially uniformly beige.
attractions: It marks its territory in several ways—leaving dung piles in visible spots, pawing the ground, and rubbing preorbital gland secretions on grasses and twigs. In Africa, you might observe a peculiar behavior: the male challenges rivals by kneeling on its front legs and presenting its horn tips.
breeding: We have kept blesboks since 1998, when a group of four arrived from Karlsruhe. The first calf, a female named Žofie, was born in 2001, followed by over 20 more offspring.
